awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Assessing Low Temperature Phase Stability through Irradiation
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:

Alloys in long-term service at moderately elevated temperatures (200-500°C), fall into a technological gap, where temperature effects are very slow but become significant over time. This temperature range is essential in many important technological industries such as aerospace, energy production and petrochemical plants. Over the period of decades, these materials can degrade and no longer perform as designed, potentially causing safety concerns. Laboratory studies of alloy degradation at these temperatures still take many years to perform and is often impractical. This project proposes to use irradiation as a tool to accelerate low temperature diffusion by creating more defects in the lattice. This method is expected to speed up the phase transformations that degrade properties by several orders of magnitude, which would make laboratory studies feasible. A long term thermal aging experiment will be performed to benchmark the irradiation results and computational simulations of atomic diffusion will be performed to help explain the differences between the two methods. Successful demonstration of the irradiation-enhanced method will allows us to identify the evolution of new, stable low-temperature phases, and to predict the service lifetime of alloys in service. Additionally, we expect to be able to use this knowledge to design new alloys that are better suited to resist long-term thermal degradation. This project is also designed to act as a vehicle for both recruiting and retaining a future generation of engineers and scientists from under-represented groups. By integration with two mentoring programs that bring Oregon high school, undergraduate and graduate students, and the professor together, a pyramid of mentorship in the laboratory is being created.
 
TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:

Alloys in long-term service at temperatures in the range of 200-500°C, fall into a technological gap, where atomistic diffusion is very slow but becomes significant and phase diagrams are, as a consequence of the slow diffusion, usually incomplete. This temperature range is essential in many important technological industries such as aerospace, energy production and petrochemical plants. By using irradiation as a positive tool for materials research we expect to be able to accurately acquire these low-temperature data through irradiation-enhanced phase transformations. Successful demonstration of the validity of this method will allow the identification of new, stable low-temperature phases, and to validate kinetic transformation models within a practical timeframe. A parallel computational study will be used to explain differences between thermal and irradiation-assisted phase transformation and give fundamental insight into the mechanisms that control the transformation in the Ni-Cr-Fe system. In turn, the design of new alloys better suited to meet forthcoming technological needs can be expected to become possible. The research components of this project advance work of the scientific community by generating an improved thermodynamic database for the Ni-Cr-Fe system and implementing it within a commercial software package. This project supports the broader goal of training the future materials workforce by arming them with state-of-the-art experimental methods and theoretical approaches for studying phase transformations. Additionally, this project will help to increase diversity in STEM fields through research opportunities for under-represented high school and undergraduate student groups through two different outreach programs. These research opportunities and a newly-developed didactic class will encourage students to explore opportunities in materials science, specifically metallurgy.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Alloys in long-term service at moderately elevated temperatures (200-500 C), fall into a technological gap, where atomistic diffusion is very slow but becomes significant over time. This temperature range is essential in many important industries such as aerospace, energy production and petrochemical plants. Over the period of decades, these materials can degrade and no longer perform as designed, potentially causing safety concerns. Knowing what phases will form in an alloy and how long they take to form is essential for appropriate alloy selection for components designed for long-term service at elevated temperatures. Laboratory studies of alloy degradation at these temperatures take many years to perform and are often impractical. Software based on results of thermodynamics and/or quantum mechanical calculations can be used, with limited success, to extrapolate the composition range of known phases to lower temperatures, however, the ability to predict new phases using such approaches has remained a challenge.

In this project, we explored using proton irradiation as a tool to accelerate low temperature phase transformations by creating more defects in the lattice, which enhance atomic diffusion. We applied this approach to Ni-Cr-based alloys that form an ordered phase with the Ni2Cr stoichiometry. This Ni2Cr phase embrittles the alloy and alters its mechanical properties. We benchmarked our irradiations with long-term thermal aging experiments and computational simulations of atomic diffusion to help explain the differences between the two methods. Additionally, we explored the role of minor impurities (e.g., P) and Fe additions (up to 10 wt.%) on the rate of Ni2Cr formation to help relate to commercial alloys.

We irradiated model Ni-Cr alloys with 0-10 wt.% Fe and a commercial alloy (alloy 690) with and without 0.01 wt.% P additions. These alloys were subject to 2 MeV proton irradiation to 1.5 dpa (displacements per atom) at 350 C. Identical alloys were isothermally aged for up to 10,000 hours at temperatures ranging from 330-475 C. Synchrotron x-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of both the irradiated and thermally aged samples determined phase fractions and precipitate sizes of the ordered Ni2Cr phase. Vickers hardness data was also collected as an indicator of the change in mechanical properties with the ordering phase transformation.  XRD analysis showed formation of Ni2Cr within irradiated alloy 690+0.01 wt.% P and the model alloys, but not in pure alloy 690. Only the model alloys with < 5 wt.% Fe showed formation of Ni2Cr after isothermal aging. We find that P impurities can accelerate the formation of Ni2Cr formation in alloy 690 under irradiation, and other minor alloying elements (e.g., Ti) in 690 may help slow Ni2Cr formation when compared to the model alloys with 10 wt.% Fe. Based on the comparison between Ni2Cr phase formation in the irradiated and thermally aged samples we find proton irradiation accelerates ordering by at least 40x.

 In addition to our irradiation study, we discovered that the mechanical property changes (i.e., hardness) associated with the formation of Ni2Cr precipitates is directly related to the average precipitate size rather than amount of Ni2Cr phase. We can now use a critically resolved shear stress model for weakly coupled dislocation to relate the precipitate size to hardness. This model works well for all thermally aged Ni-Cr model alloys where observed Ni2Cr phase (up to 7 wt.% Fe). This model will allow us to re-evaluate past literature data on Ni2Cr ordering in a consistent way using hardness data. This will support the development of time-temperature-transformation diagrams with a consistent indicator for when the transformation is detectable, which will help us to guide industry about component lifetimes.

Broader Impacts:

Successful demonstration of irradiation-enhanced phase transformations will help us to rapidly identify the evolution of new, stable low-temperature phases, and to predict the service lifetime of different alloys. Additionally, we expect to be able to use this knowledge to design new alloys that are better suited to resist long-term thermal degradation. Our studies on Ni-Cr alloys contribute to the growing body of literature that will inform models to predict when Ni-Cr-based power plant components need to be changed. These models could help power plants run more safely and efficiently, as well as guide regulatory agencies on granting plant life extensions. This impacts society in terms of safety, energy reliability and energy cost.

This project was also used to support and train one M.S. student and two Ph.D. students who will continue to work in this field. Additionally, we had a high school intern who benefited from this project and developed an outreach activity for middle school aged girls. This activity will continue to be used in our Expanding your Horizons workshop at Oregon State University. Hopefully, our efforts will excite the interest of a new generation of women to enter STEM fields, particularly with a focus on metallurgy.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/12/2023
Modified by: Julie D Tucker
